importance: This paper is important because it presents a novel and efficient approach to semantic segmentation using only approximate size targets, significantly reducing the annotation burden.  This offers **substantial improvements in efficiency** and generalizability and opens avenues for research on weakly-supervised semantic segmentation methods. The simplicity and general applicability of the method make it highly relevant for researchers dealing with limited annotations or datasets.
summary: Accurate semantic segmentation is achieved with minimal annotation effort using a novel image-level supervision method based on approximate size targets.
takeaways: Approximate size targets are sufficient for accurate semantic segmentation.
The proposed image-level supervision method significantly reduces annotation costs compared to pixel-level annotation.
The method is robust to size target errors and works on standard segmentation architectures without modifications.
tldr:
Semantic segmentation, a crucial task in computer vision, typically requires extensive pixel-level annotations which is expensive and time-consuming.  This has led researchers to explore weakly-supervised methods. However, existing methods often involve complex modifications or multiple training stages, limiting their practical applicability. This is a major challenge in the field.
This paper proposes a novel image-level supervision method that uses approximate size targets to train semantic segmentation models. Instead of requiring pixel-accurate annotations, this method only needs estimates of the relative size of objects in the image.  The authors show that using the zero-avoiding variant of KL divergence as a loss function leads to accurate segmentation results comparable to fully supervised methods. This innovative approach significantly simplifies the training process and enhances the efficiency and robustness of semantic segmentation models.
